questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:

  1. Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
  2. Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant. 
  3. Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  4. Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: Cysteine-, lactose-, electrolyte-deficient (CLED) agar medium is used in preference to MacConkey agar in relation to the culture of organisms involved in urine infection. The reason is that it  ____.

choices.text: Allows Staphylococcus and Candida to grow

questions.solution:
Cysteine-, lactose-, electrolyte-deficient (CLED) agar promotes the growth Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Candida.

CLED agar: It is used as an alternative to the combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar for the processing of urine specimens.

  • Advantages over MacConkey agar: It is less inhibitory than MacConkey agar and supports the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except beta-hemolytic Streptococcus) and Candida.
  • Advantages over blood agar: It can prevent the swarming of Proteus.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prosodemic disease?
questions.solution:
Creeping or smoldering epidemics that evolve slowly are known as prosodemic diseases. Ex: Cerebrospinal fever.

Endemic diseases: Constantly present in a particular area, e.g., malaria in Africa.

Epidemic diseases: Occurrence of cases of an illness in a community or region, which is in excess of the normal expectancy. Influenza causes annual winter epidemics in cold countries.

Pandemic diseases: Epidemic that spreads through many areas of the world involving a very large number of people within a short period, e.g., influenza, cholera.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. This means they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of loose stools and weight loss. Laboratory diagnostic tests are positive for HIV. Detection of which of the following would be most helpful in diagnosing HIV/AIDS?
questions.solution:
The acute HIV syndrome presents as acute infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever)-like syndrome.

The syndrome is characterized by the following:

General: fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, headache, arthralgia/myalgia, weight loss, vomiting/diarrhea     

Neurologic: meningitis, encephalitis, peripheral neuropathy, myelopathy

  • Lyme disease is not associated with HIV
  • Fungal infections associated with HIV-associated diarrhea are histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, and penicilliosis, not oropharyngeal candidiasis.
  • Diarrhea in HIV patients is associated with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, but not pulmonary Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) infection.

Causes of diarrhea in HIV patients:

Bacterial: Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, Clostridium difficile, and MAC.

Parasitic: Cryptosporidium, Microsporidia, Isospora belli

Fungal: histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, penicilliosis

Viral: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis

AIDS enteropathy chronic diarrheal syndrome for which no etiologic agent is found.

questions.text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test 1 month after taking the MMR vaccine. At the time of receiving the vaccine, she had been advised to avoid conception. What advice do you give her now?

choices.text: Low risk; termination of pregnancy may be considered
High risk; serious consideration for termination

questions.solution:
In this case scenario, the doctor should advise the patient to wait and watch.

The MMR vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine against measles, mumps and rubella. The vaccine should not be administered during pregnancy. However, some studies of women, who had mistakenly been administered the rubella vaccine (a component of MMR vaccine) during pregnancy, showed that their children did not develop congenital rubella syndrome. Therefore, if pregnancy occurs within 28 days of immunization, the patient should be counselled on the theoretical risks of the fetus developing congenital rubella syndrome, and termination of pregnancy should not be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal spores are formed by condensation of the hyphal elements?
questions.solution:
Arthrospores are asexual spores that are formed along the mycelium/hyphae by segmentation and condensation of hyphae.

Arthrospores are commonly formed by dermatophytes, especially those belonging to the genus Trichophyton. They are also formed by dimorphic fungi like Coccidiodes sp.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man  came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of his legs. On examination, the following findings are noted. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Progressive swelling of the legs with non-pitting edema and thickening of the overlying skin (image) is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). The best next step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. There is obstruction of lymph vessels by adult worms, resulting in lymphangitis and leakage of lymph into tissues, resulting in hard pitting lymphedema. Fibrous tissue is laid down in tissues due to repeated lymphedema, resulting in non-pitting elephantiasis. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

Other options: 

Option A: PCR is negative in chronic filariasis.

Options B & D: Lymphangiography and lymphoscintigraphy are used to assess the extent of lymphatic damage after the diagnosis of filariasis.

questions.text: Which the following filarial worms are non-pathogenic to humans?
questions.solution:
Mansonella ozzardi is generally non-pathogenic to humans. 

Option A: Onchocerca volvulus infection may manifest as skin nodules or onchocercoma which are formed as a result of fibroblastic reaction around adult worms deep in the subcutaneous tissues. Microfilariae cause lesions in the skin and eyes.

Options B and C: In lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria and Brugia), the typical manifestations are caused by the adult worms blocking lymph nodes and vessels. Microfilaria (larval form) are responsible for allergic manifestations seen in occult filariasis.

questions.text: An orthopedician is performing the following procedure to visualize the anterior cruciate ligament in a patient. Which of the following will be used to sterilise the instrument used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows arthroscopy being performed. Arthroscopes are sterilized using plasma sterilization which utilises hydrogen peroxide. 

In plasma sterilisation, radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapours are passed. This generates plasma which contains free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. Plasma denatures all organisms and is used sterilize arthroscopes and ureteroscopes. Sterilization control is monitored by Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus. 

Option A: Ethylene oxide has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity. It is used for sterilisation heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, suture materials etc. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillius atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilus.

Option B: Gamma rays cause breakage of DNA. It destroys spores and vegetative cells, but is not effective against viruses. It is referred to as cold sterilisation and is used in commercial plants to sterilize plastics, syringes, swabs. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus pumilius. 

Option D: Ultraviolet rays are used to sterilise biosafety cabinets, entryways, operation theatres and laboratories.

questions.text: A man presents with dysuria and clear urethral discharge. He is sexually active. Gram stain of a urethral swab shows neutrophils but no organisms. Which of the following is the most appropriate culture medium for the most common organism responsible for the above condition?
questions.solution:
A sexually active man with dysuria, urethral discharge and absence of bacteria on Gram staining suggests a diagnosis of non-gonococcal urethritis. The most common organism causing this is Chlamydia trachomatis and thus, the most appropriate culture medium is McCoy cells (human synovial carcinoma cell line).

C. trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacte­rium and an obligate intracellular parasite. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used to isolate the organism. C. trachomatis appears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. It causes urogenital syndromes in men and women. 

Urethritis in men can be caused by Neiserria gonorrheae, C. trachomatis, Mycoplasma genitalium, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Trichomonas vaginalis, HSV, and rarely adenovirus. Gram stain of urethral discharge from gonococcal urethritis would show the presence of ≥ 2 PMNs/1000x field and Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Chlamydial co-infection is common in gonococcal urethritis. In the absence of bacteria on Gram staining, non-gonococcal urethritis is suspected, of which 30-40% of cases are caused by Chalmydia trachomatis. 

Option B: Thayer–Martin agar is used for isolation of Neisseria spp. 

Option C: Robertson’s cooked meat is used for the culture of anaerobes, especially Clostridia

Option D: Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) broth is used to culture Mycoplasma spp. and Ureaplasma spp.

Note: In women, abnormal urethral gram stain showing >10 PMNs/1000Å~ field with dysuria but without coliform bacteriuria supports the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis.

questions.text: A patient who comes with a history of an insect bite while trekking is diagnosed to have scrub typhus. The weil-Felix reaction will show positivity for which of the following antigens?
questions.solution:
The Weil–Felix reaction for scrub typhus shows positivity for OX K.

Weil–Felix test is a heterologous agglutination test used for the diagnosis of rickettsial infections. The test detects anti-rickettsial antibodies that cross-react with O antigens of certain nonmotile strains of Proteus. In this test, nonmotile strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K are used as antigens. The Weil–Felix test becomes positive 10–20 days after infection.

  • Sera from epidemic typhus shows a strong reaction with OX 19 antigen and weakly agglutinates with OX 2 antigen. 
  • Sera from endemic typhus shows a strong reaction with OX 19 antigen and may weakly agglutinate with OX 2 antigen. 
  • Sera from scrub typhus agglutinates with OX K antigen.
  • Weil–Felix test is negative or weakly reactive in Brill–Zinsser disease.

Weil–Felix test in rickettsial diseases:

Rickettsial diseases   Agglutination  
  OX 19 OX 2 OX K
Epidemic typhus +++ +  -
Brill–Zinsser disease +/-  -  -
Endemic typhus +++ +/-  -
Spotted fever ++ ++  -
Scrub typhus  -  - +++

questions.text: A patient from Kerala has presented to your OPD with fever. A magnified view of peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the organism seen?

choices.text: DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day
Second stage filariform larva is the infective form
Microfilaria is the major diagnostic form
Filarial stage of adult worms are responsible for disease

questions.solution:
Fever with a peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. The third stage filariform larva is the infective form.

Wuchereria bancrofti infection is usually asymptomatic. The symptoms are due to obstruction of lymphatics by the filarial stage of adult worms. The lymphatic vessels of the male genitalia are most commonly affected in bancroftian filariasis, producing episodic funiculitis, epididymitis, and orchitis. Adenolymphangitis of the extremities is less common. 

Hydrocele is the most common sign of chronic bancroftian filariasis, followed by lymphedema, elephantiasis, and chyluria. The swelling involves the whole leg, the whole arm, the scrotum, the vulva, or the breast. DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day.

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given virus?

choices.text: Incubation period is less than 24 hours
Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure
It is eliminated from semen within 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The above image is of the Ebola virus showing the bowl of spaghetti appearance. Patients with Ebola virus disease are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever; intense weakness; vomiting; diarrhea; rashes; and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: A sanitation worker presents with high-grade fever and red eyes. On examination, there is icterus, neck rigidity, the sign demonstrated below. Investigations show azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. What is the most appropriate drug to be prescribed in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patient with fever, conjunctival suffusion (red-eye), jaundice, along with image showing kernig's sign positive and other meningeal signs i.e. neck rigidity is suggestive of a diagnosis of leptospirosis. This along with azotemia and elevated liver enzymes are features of severe leptospirosis- Weil's disease. Intravenous penicillin is most appropriate drug in severe leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by triad of:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury

Jaundice, when present, can be profound, and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation or relative bradycardia may also be observed. The bacteria is spread by the urine of infected animals and humans, thus making sanitary workers a high-risk population due to poor working conditions.  

The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis:

Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by microscopic agglutination test. 

Treatment for leptospirosis is based on the severity of the disease. In mild cases, oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin is preferred and in severe cases, intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone is commonly used.

questions.text: The identification of Salmonella and Shigella in stool cultures using eosin–methylene blue (EMB) medium is dependent on which of the following properties?

choices.text: Salmonella and Shigella produce a blue colony in the presence of methylene blue.
Salmonella and Shigella produce a colorless colony.
Salmonella and Shigella produce a dark blue black colony with green sheen.
Salmonella and Shigella produce a yellow colony.

questions.solution:
Salmonella and Shigella produce a colorless colony in the eosin methylene blue agar because they do not ferment lactose.  

EMB agar: Eosin methylene blue (EMB) agar is a selective, differential medium.

It is selective because it allows the growth of gram-negative rods and inhibits the growth of gram-positive organisms.

Its differential property is based on the fact that Salmonella and Shigella do not ferment lactose while other enteric gram-negative rods do.  

On EMB agar, Escherichia coli appear as dark blue-black colonies with green metallic sheen because they are lactose fermenters.

Since both Salmonella and Shigella appear colorless, triple-sugar iron agar is used to differentiate Salmonella from Shigella.

This medium contains

  • 0.1% glucose
  • 1% sucrose
  • 1% lactose
  • Ferrous sulfate (for detection of H2S production)
  • Tissue extracts (protein growth substrate)
  • A pH indicator (phenol red)

It is poured into a test tube to produce a slant with a deep butt and is inoculated by stabbing bacterial growth into the butt.  

If only glucose is fermented, the slant and the butt initially turn yellow from the small amount of acid produced; as the fermentation products are subsequently oxidized to CO2 and H2O and released from the slant and as oxidative decarboxylation of proteins continues with formation of amines, the slant turns alkaline (red).  

  • If lactose or sucrose is fermented, so much acid is produced that the slant and butt remain yellow (acid). Salmonella and Shigella typically yield an alkaline slant and an acid butt. 
  • If gas is produced, bubbles and cracks can be seen in the medium. 
  • If H2S is produced, the black color of ferrous sulfide can be seen.
Name of the organism Slant Butt Gas H2S
E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterobacter Acid Acid Positive Negative
Shigella, Serratia Alkaline Acid Negative Negative
Salmonella, Proteus Alkaline Acid Positive Positive
Pseudomonas Alkaline Alkaline Negative Negative

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode known to cause human infection. It has both a free-living and a parasitic life cycle. Its natural host is man. The infective form to man is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, the larvae migrate to the small intestine. They molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). Thus, it is ovoviviparous. These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

The rhabditiform larva can also be passed in the stool. It may directly metamorphose to the infective filariform larva in the soil, or develop into adult worms. The free-living adult worms then pass eggs, which hatch and mature to form infective filariform larvae. 

 In Ancylostoma duodenale infestation, eggs containing segmented ova (not rhabditiform larvae) are passed in the stool. The rhabditiform larva hatches 2 days after the eggs are passed in the soil. 

Note: Based on the method of reproduction, nematodes are classified as follows:

  1. Oviparous - They lay eggs:
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria
    • Segmented eggs:  Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis
  2. Viviparous - They produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi
  3. Ovoviviparous – They lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., Strongyloides stercoralis

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except ______.
questions.solution:
Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is lymphotropic virus and is closely related to Ebstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Diseases caused by HHV:

  • Kaposi sarcomas
  • Vascular tumors of mixed cellular composition
  • Body cavity-based lymphomas occurring in AIDS patients (Primary effusion lymphoma)
  • Multicentric Castleman disease

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in the autoimmune disease shown below?
questions.solution:
The disease shown in the image is myasthenia gravis. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibodies directed towards self-antigens- cell surface or extracellular matrix. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Moraxella catarrhalis?

choices.text: An uncommon cause of COPD exacerbation

questions.solution:
Moraxella catarrhalis is a DNAse positive gram-negative diplococcus. It is the second most common bacterial cause of COPD exacerbations (after H. influenzae). It can also cause otitis media, sinusitis, tracheobronchitis, and pneumonia. 

It differs from pathogenic Neisseria as:

  • It does not ferment any carbohydrates - Asaccharolytic
  • Gives a positive tributyrin hydrolysis test.
  • Shows positive DNAse test.

Angular conjunctivitis is caused by Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria.

Treatment is with oral amoxicillin and clauvulanic acid.

questions.text: A junior doctor sustained a needle-stick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of the following regimen would be the best recommendation?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

The protocol followed is :Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28 - day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

Note: The NACO October 2018 guidelines recommend the two drug regimen but the recent MOHFW JAN 2020 recommends the three drug regimen as per WHO December 2018 guidelines as the preferred treatment for PEP in HIV.

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: Envelope antigen (HbeAg) of hepatitis B is encoded by the _________.
questions.solution:
• HBeAg is coded by the C gene if the translation begins from the pre-C region.
  • HBV contains a small, partially double-stranded (DS), relaxed-circular DNA (rcDNA) genome that replicates by reverse transcription of an RNA intermediate, the pre- genomic RNA (pgRNA). The genome encodes four overlapping open reading frames (ORFs) that are translated into viral core protein, surface proteins, polymerase/reverse transcriptase (RT), and HBx.
  • S gene: It codes for surface antigen. It consists of:
    • S region,codes for S or major protein
    • 2 Pre-S regions, Pre-S1 codes for  L or large protein, Pre-S2 codes for M or middle protein
  • C gene:
    • When C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed
    • When translation begins from Pre-C region, HBeAg is formed
  • P gene: Codes for DNA polymerase
  • X gene: Codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg

questions.text: A 45-year-old fisherman presents with pain and a lesion in his hand similar to what is shown in the image.  What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a raised, well-circumscribed, violaceous lesion with the absence of pus. Thus, it is erysipeloid which is a skin infection caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae.

Erysipeloid usually occurs on the fingers by direct inoculation at the site of a cut or abrasion, in people who handle animals, fish or animal products. Pain, swelling and erythema develop and the condition has been called seal finger and whale finger. Pus is usually absent at the infection site, which helps differentiate it from staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infections. It resolves without treatment in 3-4 weeks. 

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a slender, non-motile, non-sporing Gram positive bacillus. It is catalase, oxidase, and indole negative. It causes disease in multiple land animals like swine, turkeys and sheep. 

Note: Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. It presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges.

questions.text: A woman presented with fever and retro-orbital pain for 2 days. NS1 antigen test was positive. Which of the following is true regarding the structure of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
A woman with fever, retro-orbital pain and positive NS1 antigen most likely has dengue fever. It is caused by dengue virus, an enveloped virus. The lipid of enveloped viruses is largely of host-cell origin, whereas protein is virus coded.

The envelope is a lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation, when the viral particle undergoes budding through the host cell membrane. Envelopes confer chemical, antigenic and biological properties to viruses. The following are the differences between enveloped and non-enveloped viruses.

Enveloped viruses Non-enveloped viruses
Ether sensitive Ether resistant
Heat labile Heat stable
Pleomorphic Non-pleomorphic
Susceptible to bile salts Resistant to bile salts

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

  Non-enveloped viruses Enveloped viruses
DNA viruses

Parvovirus

Adenovirus

Herpes virus

Hepatitis B virus

Poxvirus
RNA viruses

Picornavirus

Astrovirus

Reovirus

Calicivirus

Hepatitis A and E virus

Hepatitis c virus

Rubella virus

Chikungunya virus

Dengue virus

Japanese encephalitis virus

Kyasanur Forest disease virus

Zika virus

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to:
questions.solution:
The given egg belongs to whipworm or Trichuris trichiura.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

Whipworms live in the large intestine and whipworm eggs are passed in the feces of infected persons. The eggs develop in the soil in 3-4 weeks and become infective to man. When these embryonated eggs containing infective larvae contaminate food or water, they can cause infections in humans. 

 

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is a diphtheroid and is pyrazinamidase positive and urease positive?
questions.solution:
Corynebacterium hofmanni is a diphtheroid and is pyrazinamidase positive and urease positive.

  • Diphtheroids are corynebacteria, resembling Corynebacterium diphtheriae, occurring as normal commensals in the throat, skin, conjunctiva, and other areas.
  • The common diphtheroids include C. hofmanni and Cornybacterium xerosis.
  • Both C. hofmanni and C. xerosis are pyrazinamidase positive unlike C. diphtheriae.
  • C. hofmanni, also known as Corynebacterium pseudodiphtheriticum, is urease positive and non-fermentative.
  • C. xerosis is urease negative and ferments glucose.
  • Corynebacterium ulcerans is pyrazinamidase negative.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first sign of generalized tetanus?
questions.solution:
The first sign of generalized tetanus is increased tone of the masseter muscle, which results in trismus or lock-jaw.

Tetanus:

  • Route of entry of organism- injury, unhygienic surgery, abortion/delivery, otitis media
  • The incubation period is 6-10 days.
  • First clinical sign- increased masseter tone (trismus/lock-jaw) followed by descending tetanus
  • Deep tendon reflex is exaggerated.
  • In neonates, difficulty in feeding is the usual presentation.
  • Diagnosis is always clinical, microscopy is unreliable.
  • Treatment includes cleaning the entry wound first in order to remove anaerobic foci of infection and prevent further toxin production. Metronidazole is preferred for antibiotic therapy. Antitoxin should be given early in an attempt to deactivate any circulating tetanus toxin. Spasms are controlled by heavy sedation with benzodiazepines. Symptomatic treatment is given for respiratory and cardiovascular derangements.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for the past 4 months as shown in the image below. Which pathogen most commonly causes this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of onychomycosis and the pathogen most commonly associated with this condition is Trichophyton rubrum. Diabetes increases the risk of onychomycosis.

Onychomycosis refers to nail infections caused by fungi. It can be due to dermatophytes, non-dermatophytic moulds, and candida. Tinea unguium refers to nail infections caused by dermatophytes. This condition may affect toenails or fingernails, but toenail infections are particularly common. 

The following photomicrograph of the nail segment in KOH shows T. rubrum fungal hyphae invading nail cells.

The following image is of a lactophenol cotton blue(LPCB) mount showing pyriform shaped microconidia on the hyphae of T. rubrum.

Treatment for onychomycosis is with oral terbinafine or azoles for 6 weeks to 3 months, depending on the depth of infection and whether the infection is on the hand or toe nail.

questions.text: Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by  ________.
questions.solution:
Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahemolyticus.

  • On Wagatsuma agar (blood agar with 2% salt), pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic.
  • This is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

The cell wall of bacteria provides shape and ridigity to the bacterial cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans.

  Gram positive Gram negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulfur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

 

Other options:

Option C: The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan).

Option D: The cell wall of mycobacteria have mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid fastness.

questions.text: Which of the following is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Epsilometer (E-test) is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.

E-test is a modification of the agar diffusion susceptibility test. It is a quantitative technique for determining the antimicrobial susceptibility (AST) and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) in µg/mL of gram-negative and gram-positive aerobic bacteria.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

  • Diffusion methods: The drug diffuses through a solid medium so that a gradient is established. The concentration is highest near the site of drug application and decreases with distance. The test bacterium is cultured on the medium and its sensitivity to the antibiotic is determined by the zone of growth inhibition. Examples include Kirby–Bauer method and Stokes method.
  • Dilution methods: Serial dilutions of the drug are prepared and inoculated with bacteria. Examples include tube dilution method and agar dilution method
  • Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)

questions.text: Which of the following organisms most commonly causes Katayama fever?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Katayama fever is most commonly caused by Schistosoma mansoni.

It is an immune complex mediated disease caused by antibodies to the schistosomulae, adult worms, and eggs. This acute illness consists of fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and allergic manifestations. The diagnosis is by the demonstration of the eggs in feces.

Praziquantel is effective in the treatment. Glucocorticoids are given to suppress hypersensitivity reactions.

Instances of Katayama fever are rarer in infections with Schistosoma haematobium compared to S. mansoni. (Option A) 

Note: Katayama fever is most commonly caused by S. japonicum and S. mansoni. However, among the given options, S. mansoni is the most common cause of Katayama fever.

questions.text: A positive catalase test and bacitracin sensitivity are shown by ______.
questions.solution:
A positive catalase test and bacitracin sensitivity are shown by micrococci.

A positive catalase test is given by both Staphylococcus and Micrococcus.

 Differentiation between Staphylococcus and Micrococcus:

Test Staphylococcus Micrococcus
OF test Fermentative Oxidative
Furazolidone Sensitive Resistant
Bacitracin Resistant Sensitive

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Staphylococci except that ___.

choices.text: A majority of infections caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci are due to Staphylococcus epidermidis
Βeta-lactamase production in staphylococci is under plasmid control.
Expression of methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus increases when it is incubated at 37°C in blood agar.
Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is independent of β-lactamase production.

questions.solution:
The optimum temperature for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) expression is 30°C, whereas the optimum temperature for the growth of S. aureus is 37°C.

Other options:

Option a: More than 75% of infections caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) are due to Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Option b: Beta-lactamase production in staphylococci is plasmid mediated, whereas PBP 2A (mecA gene is chromosomal)

Option d: Resistance in MRSA is mediated by the mecA gene, which is chromosomally coded. It alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell membrane to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics. Thus, methicillin resistance in S. aureus is independent of β-lactamase production.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Sporangiophore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.

Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:

Class Sexual spore Asexual spore
Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospores Sporangiospores
Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia
Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia
Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes) Yet to be identified Conidia

Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.

Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with _____.
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment. 

A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood spills. 

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenetic hallmark for filovirus infections?

choices.text: There is a pronounced suppression of immune system.
DIC causes severe imbalance in the clotting system.
Extensive necrosis/hypoxic infarcts are seen in target tissues, particularly the gonads, kidneys, liver, and spleen.
It is associated with severe lymphocytosis.

questions.solution:
Severe lymphopenia is seen in patients with filovirus infections.

Filoviruses are a long, thread-like virus, hence the name.

Predominantly pleomorphic filaments but also assume torus- or 6-like shapes (width, ~80 nm; average length, ≥790 nm). 

Ebola virus and Marburg viruses, which cause hemorrhagic fever, belong to the genus filovirus.

  • The first targets of filovirus are local macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • One of the pathogenetic hallmarks of filovirus infections is a pronounced suppression of the immune system. It causes severe disturbance of the clotting system and the impairment of vascular integrity. Disseminated intravascular coagulation is the cause of the severe imbalance in the clotting system of filovirus-infected patients.

The FDA recently approved Ervebo, the first FDA-approved vaccine for the prevention of Ebola virus disease (EVD), caused by Zaire ebolavirus in individuals 18 years of age and older.

questions.text: You are performing the test shown in the image on a patient. How many days later do you ask the patient to return so that you get an accurate read on the Mitsuda reaction?
questions.solution:
Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of injection.

Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin.

The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. 

Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has a history of recurrent skin and respiratory tract infections. Investigations are carried out and a disorder of phagocytosis is suspected. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is not a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects. 

Disorders of phagocytosis:

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  • Chediak–Higashi syndrome
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia

Other options: 

Option B: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency leads to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia, and recurrent infections without pus.

Option C: Chediak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. There is neutropenia and recurrent infections. 

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A microbiologist observes the following growth on a blood agar plate. Which of the following will not be the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a swarming type of growth on the agar plate. It will not be caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Swarming is the growth of motile bacteria in the form of a thin film on solid culture media. It is exhibited by the following:

  • Gram-positive bacilli - Clostridium tetani (option A), Bacillus cereus (option D)
  • Gram-negative bacilli - Proteus mirabilis (option C), Proteus vulgaris
  • Gram-negative halophilic bacteria- Vibrio parahaemolyticus 

Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.

questions.text: A patient who had been receiving ceftazidime and amikacin via central venous line for a week suddenly spiked a fever. Blood culture is positive for a vancomycin-resistant, catalase-negative organism whose Gram-stained image is given below. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The most likely organism involved is Enterococcus faecalis. The image shows gram-positive cocci in chains that are described as catalase-negative. This helps rule out Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococcus, which are Gram-positive cocci in clusters. Streptococcus viridans is usually sensitive to penicillin and vancomycin hence it is ruled out.

The Enterococci are oval cocci arranged in short chains. They are non-hemolytic. They can cause bacteremia, especially in patients with intravascular catheters. In the USA, they are the second most common etiologic agents of central line-associated bacteremia. Recently, vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) are emerging. This is due to the alteration of D-alanyl–D-alanine chains in the cell wall. Linezolid is used for the treatment of VRE.

questions.text: Which of the following activates the classical complement pathway?
questions.solution:
The classical pathway of complement is activated by immune complexes or antigen-antibody complexes. (antigen bound to IgM or IgG).

Lipopolysaccharide of gram-negative bacteria activates the alternative complement pathway.

The binding of mannose-binding lectin to mannose residues (on the surfaces of Salmonella, Neisseria, and Listeria) activates the lectin complement pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following gives the result as shown in the image(5) below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a positive slide coagulase test which is seen with Staphylococcus aureus.
Coagulase test is used to differentiate Staphylococcus aureus (positive) from coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CONS).
Coagulase is an enzyme produced by S. aureus that converts soluble fibrinogen in plasma to insoluble fibrin. 
 
Staphylococcus aureus produces two forms of coagulase, bound and free.
 
Slide coagulase test is done to detect bound coagulase or clumping factor and does not require coagulase-reacting factor (CRF) in plasma. 

Tube coagulase test is done to detect free coagulase and requires coagulase-reacting factor (CRF)in plasma.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis?

choices.text: Nitrate test is positive in both Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis shows dysgonic growth and Mycobacterium bovis has eugonic growth.
0.5% glycerol helps growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis , but not Mycobacterium bovis.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis is resistant to pyrazinamidase 4 days but  Mycobacterium bovis is not resistant.

questions.solution:
O.5% glycerol helps in growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, but not Mycobacterium bovis.

Differences:

Test M. tuberculosis M. bovis
Niacin + -
Nitrate + -
O2 preference Aerobic Microaerophilic
Growth in TCH + -
Culture Eugonic Dysgonic
0.5% glycerol Helps growth  No effect
Sodium pyruvate Helps growth Helps growth
p-nitrogenic acid No growth  No effect
Tween hydrolysis +- -
Colony character Dry, rough, raised, irregular wrinkled surface, difficult to emulsify

Flat, smooth, moist, white; break up easily
Pyrazinamidase 4 days + -

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTC or MTBC) is a genetically related group of Mycobacterium species that can cause tuberculosis in humans or other living organisms.

M. tuberculosis complex includes the following:

  1. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  2. Mycobacterium africanum
  3. Mycobacterium orygis
  4. Mycobacterium bovis and the Bacillus Calmette–Guérin strain
  5. Mycobacterium microti
  6. Mycobacterium canetttii
  7. Mycobacterium caprae
  8. Mycobacterium pinnipedii
  9. Mycobacterium suricatte
  10. Mycobacterium mungi

questions.text: All of the following parasites are transmitted by the vector shown in the image below except ______.
questions.solution:
The above image is of a tse-tse fly. Trypanosomabrucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense are transmitted by tsetse fly. Trypomastigote in the saliva of tsetse fly contaminates bite.

Trypanosoma cruzi is transmitted by Reduviid bug (kissing or cone bug; genus Triatoma), which passes trypomastigote (flagellated form) in feces, later scratching implants them in mucosa.

T. cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pattern recognition receptor?
questions.solution:
Bone morphogenetic protein-like receptors are not pattern-recognition receptors. 

Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) are essential for the innate immune system. They identify pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) common to classes of microbes and trigger immune responses. These receptors can be found on the cell surface, detecting extracellular pathogens, or within the endosomes and cellular matrix, detecting intracellular invading viruses. 

PRRs activate pro-inflammatory pathways, promote phagocytosis in cells like macrophages, neutrophils and dendritic cells, and may act as secreted proteins binding directly to pathogens. Based on the localization and functional characteristics, PRRs are classified as:

  • Membrane-bound PRRs: 
    • Toll-like receptors (TLR)- detect microbial carbohydrates and lipoproteins (Option B)
    • C-type lectin receptors (CLR)- detect mannose residues
  • Cytoplasmic (intracellular) PRRs:
    • Nucleotide oligomerization (NOD)-like receptors (NLR) - NOD1 and NOD2 - Detects bacterial cell wall peptidoglycans (Option A)
    • RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs) - detect viral RNA (Option C)
  • Secreted PRRs

On the contrary, BMP receptors are multifunctional transmembrane serine-threonine kinase receptors that belong to the transforming growth factor β (TGF-β) superfamily, regulating cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis with no role in pattern recognition. Also, there are no receptors termed "BMP-like receptors". 

Note: A mutation in the Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) gene enhances the proliferation and reduces the apoptosis of pulmonary vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, leading to hereditary pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

questions.text: A 23-year-old presents with diarrhea, fever, and vomiting. The given bacteria is implicated. Which toll-like receptor binds to the structure of the bacteria marked A?
questions.solution:
The given image and clinical history suggest a typhoid infection. The structure marked A is the flagella of bacteria. Toll-like receptor (TLR) 5 binds to the flagella of bacteria.

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are transmembrane receptors that have an extracellular domain, that detect infecting pathogens.

  • TLR 1 - Mycobacteria and Gram-negative bacteria  
  • TLR 2 - Mycobacteria and Gram-positive bacteria
  • TLR 3 - Viral RNA 
  • TLR 4 - Gram-negative bacteria
  • TLR 5 - Flagella
  • TLR 9 - Bacterial DNA, some herpes viruses, malarial parasite 

TLRs act through the NF-KB pathway and initiate inflammation.

questions.text: In which of the following areas do B lymphocytes reside?
questions.solution:
B lymphocytes reside in the splenic follicles.

Lymphocytes include: 

  • B lymphocytes - Present in follicles of spleen and in follicles of lymph nodes
  • T lymphocytes - Present in the periarteriolar lymphoid sheaths (PALS) of spleen and paracortex of lymph node.

In a lymph node, follicles may contain a central region called germinal centre. This contains B cells that have been stimulated by an antigen. 

Thymus contains only T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules?

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells.
Peptide-binding site for MHC class I is α1/α2 groove.
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens.
β2 of MHC II binds to CD4 on TH cells.

questions.solution:
MHC class I presents endogenous antigens, while MHC class II presents exogenous antigens.

The following table shows the differentiating characteristics of MHC Class I and MHC Class II antigens.

MHC CLASS I

MHC CLASS II

Present on all nucleated cells ( except sperms) and platelets

Present on antigen presenting cells

Presents endogenous peptide antigen to  CD8+ T cells

Presents exogenous antigen to CD4+ T cells

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway

Peptide binds to α1/α2 groove

Peptide binds to α1/β1 groove

CD8 molecules bind cytotoxic T cells

CD4 molecules bind helper T cells

questions.text: A surgeon takes the following 2 images of a patient's arm 6 weeks apart. Which of the following mediators promote the process shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows wound healing. TGF-β (transforming growth factor-β) is responsible for wound healing.

TGF-β is produced by B and T cells and it inhibits their proliferation. It acts as a growth factor for fibroblasts and promotes wound healing. It stimulates the production of collagen, fibronectin and proteoglycans. It also promotes class switching of B cells to IgA. IL-10 is also involved in wound healing and suppression of inflammation. 

Option B: IFN-α inhibits viral replication, activates NK cells, and regulates the activity of macrophages and T cells.

Option C: TNF-α is involved in tumour cytotoxicity, phagocytic cell activation, and antiviral and antiparasitic effects. It is an acute phase protein. 

Option D: IFN-β has antiviral activity. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: While assessing the quality of drinking water in a village, you detect the presence of coliform bacilli by the multiple tube technique. Following this, you decide to perform the Eijkman test. What is this test also known as?
questions.solution:
Eijkman test is also known as differential coliform test. 

Drinking water should be free of any pathogenic microorganisms. The presence of coliform bacteria in the water may indicate faecal pollution, while the detection of E.coli confirms it. The presumptive coliform test is done by the multiple-tube technique. Following this, the Eijkman test is done to confirm the presence of E. coli. They can grow at 44°C (faecal thermotolerant bacilli), ferment lactose and cause indole and gas production.

In this test, the bottles of the presumptive coliform test showing acid and gas are subcultured to tubes of single-strength MacConkey medium, which are then incubated at 44°C. After 24 hours, tubes with gas are said to have E. Coli. The number of bacteria present in the water sample is determined using McCrady's probability tables.

Option A: Presumptive coliform count detects the probable number of coliform bacilli in water. It can be positive due to the presence of organisms other than E.coli.

Option C: Colony counts provide an estimate of the general bacterial purity of water.

Option D: Methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacterial contamination of milk.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is _____.
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Presumptive coliform count

  • The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium, which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time.
  • The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism or combination of organisms, and the presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed.
  • The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and on the medium used.
  • Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.

questions.text: A 46-year-old farmer came to the clinic with cough and chest pain for one week and fatigue for a month. A CT scan of his thorax is shown below . Which of the following classes does the causative organism of this disease belong to?
questions.solution:
Cough, chest pain, fatigue and CT scan showing a cyst with water-lily sign are suggestive of hydatid disease. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus which belongs to the class cestodes.

Echinococcus granulosus is a tape-like, segmented worm. It infects man accidentally, liberating hexacanth embryos. These embryos can be trapped in the liver or lung, giving rise to hydatid cysts. Most infections are asymptomatic. In most cases, the liver is affected and patients present with abdominal pain, obstructive jaundice and hepatomegaly. The second most common site is the lung, leading to cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and dyspnea. 

The image below shows the classification of parasites.

Note: Zoonoses refers to diseases caused by zoonotic organisms. It is not a class of organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following refers to a host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development?
questions.solution:
A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as the paratenic host.

For example, in the lifecycle of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), humans are the definitive host. The first intermediate host is cyclops and the second is small freshwater fish. If the small freshwater fish with the plerocercoid larva get eaten by a larger fish, the larva survives in the larger fish. This makes the larger fish a paratenic host.

The host is an organism that harbors the parasite and provides nourishment and shelter to it. It is relatively larger than the parasite. The types of hosts include: 

  • Definitive host: This host harbors the adult parasite and its stages of sexual reproduction.
  • Intermediate host: This host harbors the larva or the stages of asexual multiplication of the parasite.
  • Paratenic host: This host harbors only the larval stage of the parasite which does not develop further. 
  • Reservoir host: This host harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts, especially in endemic areas.
  • Accidental host: This host harbors a parasite that is not usually found in the host.

questions.text: In a patient with a positive Casoni's skin test,  which of the following infections will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s skin test is done in patients with hydatid disease.

It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction (type I). Sterile hydatid fluid is injected (0.2 mL) intradermally in one arm and an equal volume of saline as control is injected in the other arm. In a positive reaction, a large wheal appears within half an hour. A secondary reaction consisting of edema and induration appears after 8 hours. 

This test is abandoned now due to non-specificity and has been supplemented by serological tests.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

Skin test

Diagnosis

Hydatid disease

Montenegro test/Leishmanin test

Toxoplasmosis

Schistosomiasis
