Trichinellosis

questions.text: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human small intestine?
questions.solution:
Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum.

Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include:

  • Isospora belli
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Sarcocystis hominis

Other options:

Options A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human large intestine.

Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract.

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented to the OPD complaining of blood-streaked stools. Sigmoidoscopy was done and it showed ulcers in the sigmoid. Biopsy was taken from this area and the histopathological image is given below.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amoebiasis. The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole.

The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region.

Three classes of drugs are used in the treatment of amebiasis:

  • Luminal amoebicides- diloxanide furoate, iodoquinol, paromomycin, and tetracycline. They act in the intestinal lumen but not in tissues.
  • Tissue amoebicides- emetine and chloroquine. They are effective in systemic infection but less effective in the intestine.
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides- Metronidazole, tinidazole and imidazole. They act on both sites and are the drug of choice for treating amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A college student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and corneal ulcers following the use of contact lens. The saline mount preparation of the corneal scraping shows polygonal cysts. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a patient with ocular symptoms after using contact lenses most likely has an infection. The demonstration of polygonal cysts is suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is a free-living amoeba. It exists as trophozoite forms and resistant cystic forms. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, ingestion of cysts, or directly through traumatized skin or eyes.

It presents as two chronic conditions- acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented to you with fever, malaise, and weight loss. On examination, you notice the finding shown in the image. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
questions.solution:
The given image shows posterior cervical lymphadenopathy which is called Winterbottom’s sign. It is seen in West African sleeping sickness.

It is seen in stage I of West African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense.

The table below shows diseases caused by various Trypanosoma species.

Protozoa

Disease

Trypanosoma brucei gambiense

West African sleeping sickness

Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense

East African sleeping sickness

Trypanosoma cruzi

Chagas’ disease/South American trypanosomiasis

questions.text: Which is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life. 

Treatment of atrial fibrillation in HCM:

  • Amiodarone - drug of choice
  • Disopyramide
  • Radiofrequency ablation for medically refractory cases
  • Anticoagulation to prevent embolic events

Note: A sustained arrhythmia is one that lasts for >30 seconds.

questions.text: Which factor forms the basis of co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Protein A forms the basis of the co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus.

Protein A bearing staphylococci are coated with IgG antiserum. Protein A binds to the Fc terminal of IgG, leaving the Fab terminal free to combine with its specific antigen. The corresponding antigen is then added to this mixture which causes agglutination of the bacteria. This is known as the co-agglutination reaction. It is used for streptococcal, gonococcal or hemophilus typing.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about pertussis toxin?

choices.text: It is expressed on the surface of the bacillus.
"A" portion of A-B structure  is the enzymatically active moiety.
It is similar to cholera toxin in its structure and function.

questions.solution:
Pertussis toxin (PT) can be toxoided.

PT is one of the toxins produced by Bordetella pertussis. It is expressed on the surface of the bacillus and secreted into the surrounding medium. It has an A-B structure, the A portion being the enzymatically active moiety and B, the binding component. PT is similar to cholera toxin in its structure and function. PT has ADP-ribosylating activity and acts on inhibitory Gi α subunit of G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR), whereas cholera toxin acts on stimulatory Gs α subunit of GPCR.

Pertussis toxoid is the major component of the acellular pertussis vaccine. A toxoid is a toxin that has lost its toxicity but retains its antigenicity. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: What is Elek’s gel precipitation test used to test?
questions.solution:
Elek's test is used to test the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Elek's gel precipitation test is an in vitro immunoprecipitation (immunodiffusion) test used to determine whether or not a strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxigenic.  In this test, a rectangular strip of filter paper impregnated with diphtheria antitoxin is placed on the surface of a 20% normal horse serum agar. Narrow streaks of the C. diphtheriae strains are made at right angles to the filter paper strip with positive and negative controls. If the strain produces toxins, the toxin will diffuse in the agar and produce a line of precipitation (arrowhead) where it meets the antitoxin at optimum concentration. 

The test is shown in the image below.

Option A: For checking susceptibility to diphtheria, Schick test is used.

Option B: The biotype of diphtheria can be determined based on colony morphology and biochemical reactions.

Option D: The antibody titer against diphtheria can be measured by various serological methods like passive haemagglutination, latex agglutination test, toxoid enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (Toxoid-ELISA), and toxin-binding inhibition ELISA (ToBI-ELISA).

questions.text: A patient has chronic cough with occasional blood in the sputum. He has a history of significant weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following media cannot be used to culture the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include:

  • Solid- Loeffler's medium is a serum-containing solid medium used for the culture of M. tuberculosis. Other solid media used include Lowenstein- Jensen medium, Dorset medium, Tarshis medium, and Pawlowsky's medium.
  • Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and in sensitivity testing.  Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium.
  • Automated culture methods: 
    • BACTEC 460- uses radioisotopes for detection
    • BacT alert- colorimetric method of detection
    • BACTEC MGIT- fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: Which of the following components of M. tuberculosis disrupts mitochondrial function?
questions.solution:
Cord factor, is a glycolipid molecule found in the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and similar species. It disrupts mitochondrial function and inhibits leucocyte migration.

Other Options:

  • Option A: Mycolic acid is a fatty acid component present in the cell wall.  It is responsible for acid-fastness of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
  • Option C: Wax-D component of mycobacterial cell wall is associated with induction of osteomyelitis.
  • Option D: Sulfatides inhibit phagolysosome formation and allow intracellular survival.

 Other virulence factors are as follows:

  • Phospholipids: Induce caseous necrosis
  • Muramyl dipeptide (from peptidoglycan): Causes granuloma formation with mycolic acid.

questions.text: A patient presents early in the morning to the DOTS center to provide sputum samples. Which of the following reagents are used in the digestion and decontamination of his samples before smear preparation?
questions.solution:
NaOH and N-acetylcysteine are used for the digestion and decontamination of sputum used in smear preparation for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Sputum and specimens from non-sterile sites need prior treatment for digestion (to liquefy the thick pus), decontamination (to inhibit the normal flora), and concentration (to increase the yield) before they can be used for testing.

Methods used for digestion and decontamination of sputum: 

  • Petroff’s method- Uses 4% NaOH and HCl. 
  • N-acetyl cysteine (NALC) + 2% NaOH - NALC liquefies the sputum and NaOH kills the normal flora. This method is better suited for automated culture systems and is superior to Petroff’s method. 

Note: Formalin or hypochlorite can be used only if smear microscopy is being done. They are not useful for culture or animal pathogenicity testing.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning?
questions.solution:
Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that have not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. There is consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.

A second compound is thought to play a causative role in this intoxication because large doses of oral histamine do not reproduce the affliction. The toxin or toxins involved are heat stable and are not destroyed by cooking or freezing.

Symptoms develop within 15–90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8–12 h.

questions.text: Which of the following differentiates meningococcus from gonococcus?
questions.solution:
Only meningococcus can ferment maltose, whereas both gonococcus and meningococcus can ferment glucose.

Both species are catalase and oxidase positive and neither of them can reduce nitrate. The only Neisseria species that can reduce nitrate is N. mucosa.

Related Pearl: Comparison between Meningococci and Gonococci

Spread Respiratory or oral secretions  Sexual or perinatal transmission
Plasmids Rare  Has plasmids that code for drug resistance

Vaccine

Capsule-based polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines available 

(except for Type B - subcapsular antigen-based vaccine is available) 

 No vaccine due to antigenic variation of pilus proteins

Capsule

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding slow virus infections?

choices.text: Long course of illness with short incubation period
Long incubation period with a short course of illness
Long course of illness and long incubation period
Short incubation period with a short course of illness

questions.solution:
Characteristics of slow virus infections:

  • Incubation periods are long, lasting from months to years
  • Course of illness lasting for months or years, with remissions and exacerbations
  • Predilection for the involvement of CNS
  • Absence of immune response
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Invariably fatal termination

questions.text: An 18-year-old went on an exchange program to Singapore. An adventurous eater, she tried clams and oysters on a cruise ship. 2 days later, she developed fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, vomiting and diarrhea following consumption of food on a cruise ship suggest a diagnosis of Norwalk infection. 

Norwalk virus is a positive-sense ssRNA virus belonging to the family Caliciviridae. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in older children and adults. It occurs in group settings such as banquet halls, cruise ships, dormitories, and campgrounds, where outbreak sources are usually contaminated food and/or water. Potential sources of contaminated food include shellfish such as clams and oysters, which are contaminated by water.  Clinical features include fever, headache nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Symptoms of gastroenteritis develop 12 to 48 hours after being exposed to norovirus.

The image below is an electron micrograph of Norovirus (Norwalk virus).

questions.text: Strychnine toxin acts by blocking the action of glycine at the post-synaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. Which of the following has a similar mechanism of action but acts presynaptically?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxin has similar mechanisms of action as strychnine but acts pre-synaptically.

Strychnine prevents the uptake of glycine at inhibitory synapses post-synaptically, while tetanospasmin blocks release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) pre-synaptically. This leads to increased release of acetylcholine, thereby leading to the development of spastic paralysis.

The image below depicts the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying ____________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

Streptococci belonging to group A are identified (presumptively) by inhibition of growth by bacitracin.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Cutaneous infections/diseases caused by Streptococcus pyogenes

Direct infections of skin or subcutaneous tissue

  • Cellulitis
  • Impetigo
  • Ecthyma, Erysipelas
  • Vulvovaginitis
  • Perianal infection
  • Streptococcal ulcers
  • Blistering distal dactylitis
  • Necrotizing fasciitis

Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

Tissue damage from circulating toxin

  • Scarlet fever
  • Toxic‐shock‐like syndrome
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

Skin lesions due to allergic hypersensitivity to Streptococcal antigens

  • Erythema nodosum
  • Vasculitis

Skin disease provoked or influenced by Streptococcal infection (mechanism uncertain)

  • Psoriasis, especially guttate forms
  • Kawasaki disease

questions.text: Which of the following methods will not help you visualize the bacterial cell wall?
questions.solution:
The cell wall of bacteria cannot be seen with simple stains or direct light microscopy.

The bacterial cell wall is present outside the plasma membrane and confers strength and shape to the cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans. The cell wall can be demonstrated by the following methods:

  • Plasmolysis
  • Microdissection
  • Reaction with specific antibodies
  • Mechanical rupture of the cell
  • Differential staining procedures (E.g. Chance's method)
  • Electron microscopy
  • Fluorescence microscopy

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to?
questions.solution:
Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to cefotetan.

B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, polymixin, first and second-generation cephalosporins (e.g. cefotetan) and carboxypenicillins. This antimicrobial resistance is mediated by efflux pumps, antimicrobial degradation, modifying enzymes or altered membrane functions.

B. cepacia is a Gram-negative bacillus which can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include meropenem, ceftazidime, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, piperacillin and temocillin.

questions.text: A farmer was diagnosed with brucellosis. Which of the following patterns of fever will be seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. 

Other options

Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days.

Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria.

Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue.  Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C  with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.
